pull.title: abi: Use dllexport for mingw builds
pull.body:
Addresses the first part of #1181. See the discussion there for more context and history.

After this, all that remains is a (platform-independent) exports checker for c-i. Or perhaps a linker script or .def file could be tricked into testing as a side-effect.

This should fix mingw exports, specifically hiding the following:
`secp256k1_pre_g_128`
`secp256k1_pre_g`
`secp256k1_ecmult_gen_prec_table`

This changes our visibility macros to look more like [gcc's recommendation](https://gcc.gnu.org/wiki/Visibility#How_to_use_the_new_C.2B-.2B-_visibility_support).

Edit:
Note that we could further complicate this by supporting `__attribute__ ((dllexport))` as well, though I didn't bother as I'm not sure what compiler combo would accept that but not the bare dllexport syntax.

Edit2:
As the title implies, this affects this ABI and could affect downstream libs/apps in unintended ways (though it's hard to imagine any real downside). Though because it's win32 only, I'm imagining very little real-world impact at all.

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

events.body:
@real-or-random We should probably add a changelog entry for this (if you agree with it, and once we have a test for it): 

> Symbol visibility is now believed to be handled properly on supported platforms and is now considered to be part of the ABI. Please report any improperly exported symbols as a bug.

> This should fix mingw exports,

Concept ACK on this.

> As the title implies, this affects this ABI and could affect downstream libs/apps in unintended ways (though it's hard to imagine any real downside). Though because it's win32 only, I'm imagining very little real-world impact at all.

Yeah, I wouldn't consider it an ABI or an API change. IIUC the worst that can happen is that someone (wrongly) used one of these symbols in the past and now the dynamic linker can't find it anymore.
I've verified the cross-compiled DLLs on Windows using the `dumpbin /exports` command. I can confirm that this PR indeed hides the mentioned symbols.
When cross-compiling for Windows, in which cases is the `SECP256K1_BUILD` macro defined, and `DLL_EXPORT` is not defined?

FWIW, I've rebased https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1135 on top of this PR and integrated it into CI: https://github.com/hebasto/secp256k1/tree/pr1295/0505.test.2

Only "{x86_64|i686} (MSVC): Windows (Debian stable, Wine...)" jobs [fail](https://cirrus-ci.com/build/6390887589085184).

> When cross-compiling for Windows, in which cases is the `SECP256K1_BUILD` macro defined, and `DLL_EXPORT` is not defined?

When building a static libsecp256k1.

> FWIW, I've rebased #1135 on top of this PR and integrated it into CI: https://github.com/hebasto/secp256k1/tree/pr1295/0505.test.2
> 
> Only "{x86_64|i686} (MSVC): Windows (Debian stable, Wine...)" jobs [fail](https://cirrus-ci.com/build/6390887589085184).

It's not clear to me what the error is here?

> > FWIW, I've rebased #1135 on top of this PR and integrated it into CI: [hebasto/secp256k1@`pr1295`/0505.test.2](https://github.com/hebasto/secp256k1/tree/pr1295/0505.test.2?rgh-link-date=2023-05-05T14%3A42%3A01Z)
> > Only "{x86_64|i686} (MSVC): Windows (Debian stable, Wine...)" jobs [fail](https://cirrus-ci.com/build/6390887589085184).
> 
> It's not clear to me what the error is here?

Symbols are still [exported](https://cirrus-ci.com/task/5455323922694144):
```
python3 ./tools/symbol-check.py .libs/secp256k1-2.dll
.libs/secp256k1-2.dll: export of function ?_OptionsStorage@?1??__local_stdio_printf_options@@9@9 not expected
.libs/secp256k1-2.dll: export of function secp256k1_ecmult_gen_prec_table not expected
.libs/secp256k1-2.dll: export of function secp256k1_pre_g not expected
.libs/secp256k1-2.dll: export of function secp256k1_pre_g_128 not expected
.libs/secp256k1-2.dll: failed EXPORTED_FUNCTIONS
```

But it is not mingw compiler.

events.message:
abi: Use dllexport for mingw builds

This should fix mingw exports, specifically hiding the following:
secp256k1_pre_g_128
secp256k1_pre_g
secp256k1_ecmult_gen_prec_table

This changes our visibility macros to look more like gcc's recommendation:
https://gcc.gnu.org/wiki/Visibility#How_to_use_the_new_C.2B-.2B-_visibility_support

events.body: re-ACK bc7c8db179a56cf7273f3c4c0decd10543a10521, only a comment has been adjusted since my recent [review](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/1295#pullrequestreview-1414928537),
Ping @real-or-random. Anything left to do here?

issue.title: Upstream PRs 1314, 1317, 1318, 1316, 1327, 1310, 1328, 1333, 1330, 1334, 1337, 1341, 1339, 1350, 1349, 1338, 1129, 1347, 1336, 1295, 1354, 1355, 1356
issue.body:
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1314]: release cleanup: bump version after 0.3.2
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1317]: Make fe_cmov take max of magnitudes
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1318]: build: Enable -DVERIFY for precomputation binaries
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1316]: Do not invoke fe_is_zero on failed set_b32_limit
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1327]: ci: Move wine prefix to /tmp to avoid error D8037 in cl.exe
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1310]: Refine release process
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1328]: build: Bump MSVC warning level up to W3
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1333]: test: Warn if both `VERIFY` and `COVERAGE` are defined
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1330]: refactor: take use of `secp256k1_scalar_{zero,one}` constants
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1334]: fix input range comment for `secp256k1_fe_add_int`
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1337]: ci: Fix error D8037 in `cl.exe` (attempt 2)
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1341]: docs: correct `pubkey` param descriptions for `secp256k1_keypair_{xonly_,}pub`
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1339]: scalar: refactor: use `secp256k1_{read,write}_be32` helpers
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1350]: scalar: introduce and use `secp256k1_{read,write}_be64` helpers
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1349]: Normalize ge produced from secp256k1_pubkey_load
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1338]: Drop no longer needed `#include "../include/secp256k1.h"`
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1129]: ElligatorSwift + integrated x-only DH
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1347]: field: Document return value of fe_sqrt()
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1336]: Use `__shiftright128` intrinsic in `secp256k1_u128_rshift` on MSVC
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1295]: abi: Use dllexport for mingw builds
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1354]: Add ellswift to CHANGELOG
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1355]: Fix a typo in the error message
[bitcoin-core/secp256k1#1356]: ci: Adjust Docker image to Debian 12 "bookworm"

This PR can be recreated with `./contrib/sync-upstream.sh -b sync-upstream range 799f4eec`.
Tip: Use `git show --remerge-diff` to show the changes manually added to the merge commit.

comments.body: Can you update this comment to say that we slightly deviate from the suggestion in the libtool manual because the mingw linker apparently respects `_declspec (dllexport)` but not `_attribute__ ((visibility ("default"))`?
@real-or-random Sure thing. Can you link me to that? I remember you posting a link in one of these issues but I've lost it now.
Updated to include our reference as opposed to what we _don't_ use. This ok?
